## Write a better README
A README is a file that includes a detailed description of a project directory.
They typically include a broad overview of what the project does, why it was made, and the rationale behind the way it was implemented.
They also usually include instructions for how to install, run other otherwise make sense of the code and its components.
READMEs may also include links to other related resources, recognize the roles of various contributors, update users regarding the status of the project, and indicate the project's overall orientation.

[makeareadme.com](https://www.makeareadme.com/) is a great resource that provides excellent tips for writing clear and helpful readmes.
They also provide handy templates that you may adapt for your own purposes.

## Add an open license
Visit [choosealicense.com](https://choosealicense.com/) for detailed information on software licenses.

Note that software licenses are distinct from licenses intended for non-software materials, such as data, media, documentation and fonts.
choosealicense.com also includes info on non-software licenses: https://choosealicense.com/non-software/

There is also an info page on what happens if you don't choose a license: https://choosealicense.com/no-permission/

The Hippocratic License hosts a tool for creating a custom license including language suited to various parameters which you can mix and match at your own discretion, including explicit allowances and restrictions for various communities of potential use-cases, such as an Fossil Fuel Divestment module, a Law Enforcement module, and a Supply Chain Transparency module: https://firstdonoharm.dev/build/
